channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: London Underground workers go on strike, leaving millions of commuters stranded
item.description: One of the world's oldest and busiest subway systems has ground to halt. London Underground workers are on strike, leaving some 4 million commuters stranded.

item.title: Sen. Richard Blumenthal discusses his bill proposing additional sanctions on Russia
item.description: NPR speaks with U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., about his bipartisan bill proposing additional sanctions on Russia and new penalties for its trading partners, including China.

item.title: Trump continues to threaten Russia with sanctions over war in Ukraine
item.description: President Trump has repeatedly threatened to impose sanctions against Russia if it doesn't move toward a ceasefire or ending the war with Ukraine. But Russia is escalating its attacks.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: SCOTUS clears way for sweeping immigration operations to resume in L.A., Trump continues to threaten unmoved Russia with sanctions, House committee releases some documents from Epstein's estate.

item.title: New Zealand embarks on one of the most ambitious conservation projects in the world
item.description: New Zealand has set a goal of exterminating millions of rats, possums and other invasive species that pose a threat to the country's biodiversity.

item.title: Supreme Court to decide whether it will take up tariffs case
item.description: The Supreme Court is expected to decide this week whether it will consider the legality of President Trump's use of emergency powers to impose country-specific tariffs.

item.title: Can the United Nations survive the Trump administration?
item.description: The U.N., created 80 years ago to maintain international peace and security, has recently struggled with the wars in Ukraine and Gaza. It also faces a new challenge — the Trump administration.

item.title: Here are some of the best student podcasts in America
item.description: NPR's Student Podcast Challenge received nearly 2,000 entries from all around the country. Here are some of this year's best middle school submissions.

item.title: French President Emmanuel Macron appoints defense minister as new prime minister
item.description: Sébastien Lecornu, 39, is a Macron loyalist who has served as defense minister since 2022. The National Assembly ousted former Prime Minister François Bayrou in a no-confidence vote on Monday.

item.title: Trump wants to win AI race, but his immigration policies could get in the way
item.description: President Trump says he wants the U.S. to be a world leader on AI development, but his administration's immigration policies could interfere with that goal.
